newsitem.title: UK: IRA truce report treated with caution in N.Ireland.
newsitem.headline: IRA truce report treated with caution in N.Ireland.

text.p: IRA guerrillas may be moving towards a new ceasefire, Irish media reports said on Monday, but their Sinn Fein political wing ruled out an early truce and pro-British Protestants said they were sceptical.
Irish newspapers predicted peace moves by the outlawed Irish Republican Army (IRA) that has fought to end British rule of Northern Ireland for 25 years and broke a 17-month truce in February.
Quoting security sources, press reports said the leadership of the IRA may be planning a special secret convention to consider restoring the truce.
"IRA's top command structure may call a ceasefire," the Irish Times said supporting British newspaper reports that the guerrillas are planning a secret conference to decide strategy.
The Irish Independent, also published in Dublin, said senior police officers in the Irish capital believe that most of the IRA's leaders favour reinstating the ceasefire.
Sinn Fein's chief stategist, Martin McGuinness, said he had no knowledge of the guerrillas' intentions.

Accusing Britain of "dogged intransigence", McGuinness said in radio interviews that there was little prospect of an IRA ceasefire before Britain brings Sinn Fein into talks on a permanent political solution for the province.
"I think that anyone who thinks that it (an imminent truce) is likely -- given the events of the past two years -- is living in cloud cookoo land," he said on BBC radio.
The IRA launched a bombing campaign in February in mainland Britain but it has not set an attack since June 15.

The powerful Protestant Ulster Unionist Party (UUP) accused London and Dublin of creating false impressions to pave the way for Sinn Fein to join multi-party talks under way in Belfast. Sinn Fein is barred because the IRA refuses to end hostilities.

UUP politician Jeffrey Donaldson, who wants the British presence in Northern Ireland to remain, insisted there must be a permanent end to violence before Sinn Fein could be considered for a talks seat.
"I am not sure that we are going to see that," he said on his way into the talks, launched in June under the chairmanship of former U.S. senator George Mitchell.
Nigel Dodds of the Democratic Unionst Party said: "Any announcement from the IRA will be viewed with the greatest degree of scepticism possible by Unionists, who (have) heard it all before."
McGuinness put the onus for a positive move by the IRA on the British government.

"On this occasion, I believe it is absolutely essential, if there is to be any hope whatsoever of gaining a second IRA cessation that the British government must move...to put in place the process of real, meaningful negotiations."

According to the Irish media, recent setbacks including explosives siezures have fuelled a new mood which is swinging support behind the "peace strategy" spearheaded by Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams, and his chief lieutenant McGuinness.
Irish Prime Minister John Bruton caused puzzlement at home when he said during a trip to the United States last week that an IRA ceasefire might be on the cards.

The Irish Times reported that Bruton had been briefed by security chiefs that "there had been very clear intelligence reports of preparations for an IRA General Army Convention preceding a ceasefire".
